texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The OpenStack Zuul system has gone through some big changes recently, and one of those changes is around how you monitor a running CI job. I work on OpenStack-Ansible quite often, and the gate jobs can take almost an hour to complete at times. It can be helpful to watch the output of a Zuul job to catch a problem or follow a breakpoint.
texts.text: The OpenStack Zuul system has gone through some big changes recently, and one of those changes is around how you monitor a running CI job. I work on OpenStack-Ansible quite often, and the gate jobs can take almost an hour to complete at times. It can be helpful to watch the output of a Zuul job to catch a problem or follow a breakpoint.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: New Zuul
texts.text: New Zuul

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In the previous version of Zuul, you could access the Jenkins server that was running the CI job and monitor its progress right in your browser. Today, you can  monitor the progress of a job via telnet . It's much easier to use and it's a lighter-weight way to review a bunch of text.
texts.text: In the previous version of Zuul, you could access the Jenkins server that was running the CI job and monitor its progress right in your browser. Today, you can  monitor the progress of a job via telnet . It's much easier to use and it's a lighter-weight way to review a bunch of text.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Some of you might be saying:  "It's 2016. Telnet? Unencrypted? Seriously?"
texts.text: Some of you might be saying:  "It's 2016. Telnet? Unencrypted? Seriously?"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Before you get out the pitchforks, all of the data is read-only in the telnet session, and nothing sensitive is transmitted. Anything that comes through the telnet session is content that exists in an open source repository within OpenStack. If someone steals the output of the job, they're not getting anything valuable.
texts.text: Before you get out the pitchforks, all of the data is read-only in the telnet session, and nothing sensitive is transmitted. Anything that comes through the telnet session is content that exists in an open source repository within OpenStack. If someone steals the output of the job, they're not getting anything valuable.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I was having a lot of trouble figuring out how to set up a handler for
texts.text: I was having a lot of trouble figuring out how to set up a handler for

texts.label: code
texts.orig: telnet://
texts.text: telnet://

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: URL's that I clicked in Chrome or Firefox. If I clicked a link in Chrome, it would be passed off to
texts.text: URL's that I clicked in Chrome or Firefox. If I clicked a link in Chrome, it would be passed off to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: xdg-open
texts.text: xdg-open

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . I'd press OK on the window and then nothing happened.
texts.text: . I'd press OK on the window and then nothing happened.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Creating a script
texts.text: Creating a script

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First off, I needed a script that would take the URL coming from an application and actually do something with it. The script will receive a URL as an argument that looks like
texts.text: First off, I needed a script that would take the URL coming from an application and actually do something with it. The script will receive a URL as an argument that looks like

texts.label: code
texts.orig: telnet://SERVER_ADDRESS:PORT
texts.text: telnet://SERVER_ADDRESS:PORT

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and that must be handed off to the
texts.text: and that must be handed off to the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: telnet
texts.text: telnet

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: executable. Here's my basic script:
texts.text: executable. Here's my basic script:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
#!/bin/bash

# Remove the telnet:// and change the colon before the port
# number to a space.
TELNET_STRING=$(echo $1 | sed -e 's/telnet:\/\///' -e 's/:/ /')

# Telnet to the remote session
/usr/bin/telnet $TELNET_STRING

# Don't close out the terminal unless we are done
read -p "Press a key to exit"
texts.text:
#!/bin/bash

# Remove the telnet:// and change the colon before the port
# number to a space.
TELNET_STRING=$(echo $1 | sed -e 's/telnet:\/\///' -e 's/:/ /')

# Telnet to the remote session
/usr/bin/telnet $TELNET_STRING

# Don't close out the terminal unless we are done
read -p "Press a key to exit"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I saved that in
texts.text: I saved that in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ~/bin/telnet.sh
texts.text: ~/bin/telnet.sh

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . A quick test with localhost should verify that the script works:
texts.text: . A quick test with localhost should verify that the script works:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ chmod +x ~/bin/telnet.sh
$ ~/bin/telnet.sh telnet://127.0.0.1:12345
Trying 127.0.0.1...
telnet: connect to address 127.0.0.1: Connection refused
Press a key to exit
texts.text:
$ chmod +x ~/bin/telnet.sh
$ ~/bin/telnet.sh telnet://127.0.0.1:12345
Trying 127.0.0.1...
telnet: connect to address 127.0.0.1: Connection refused
Press a key to exit

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Linking up with GNOME
texts.text: Linking up with GNOME

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We need a
texts.text: We need a

texts.label: code
texts.orig: .desktop
texts.text: .desktop

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: file so that GNOME knows how to run our script. Save a file like this to
texts.text: file so that GNOME knows how to run our script. Save a file like this to

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ~/.local/share/applications/telnet.desktop
texts.text: ~/.local/share/applications/telnet.desktop

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[Desktop Entry]
Version=1.0
Name=Telnet
GenericName=Telnet
Comment=Telnet Client
Exec=/home/major/bin/telnet.sh %U
Terminal=true
Type=Application
Categories=TerminalEmulator;Network;Telnet;Internet;BBS;
MimeType=x-scheme/telnet
X-KDE-Protocols=telnet
Keywords=Terminal;Emulator;Network;Internet;BBS;Telnet;Client;
texts.text:
[Desktop Entry]
Version=1.0
Name=Telnet
GenericName=Telnet
Comment=Telnet Client
Exec=/home/major/bin/telnet.sh %U
Terminal=true
Type=Application
Categories=TerminalEmulator;Network;Telnet;Internet;BBS;
MimeType=x-scheme/telnet
X-KDE-Protocols=telnet
Keywords=Terminal;Emulator;Network;Internet;BBS;Telnet;Client;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Change the path in
texts.text: Change the path in

texts.label: code
texts.orig: Exec
texts.text: Exec

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to match where you placed your script.
texts.text: to match where you placed your script.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We need to tell GNOME how to handle the
texts.text: We need to tell GNOME how to handle the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: x-scheme-handler/telnet
texts.text: x-scheme-handler/telnet

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: mime type. We do that with
texts.text: mime type. We do that with

texts.label: code
texts.orig: xdg
texts.text: xdg

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: utilities:
texts.text: utilities:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
$ xdg-mime default telnet.desktop x-scheme-handler/telnet
$ xdg-mime query default x-scheme-handler/telnet
telnet.desktop
texts.text:
$ xdg-mime default telnet.desktop x-scheme-handler/telnet
$ xdg-mime query default x-scheme-handler/telnet
telnet.desktop
